abstract.p: Joan Schwartz letter on Oct 19 article scores response of Jonathan Cole, Columbia University provost and dean, to Prof Edward W Said's hurling of a rock toward Israeli guardhouse from Lebanese border in July

block.p: Re ''Columbia Debates a Professor's 'Gesture' '' (news article, Oct. 19), about the school's response to Edward W. Said's throwing a rock toward an Israeli guardhouse from the Lebanese border:
It strikes me that the reasoning of Jonathan Cole, the provost and dean of faculties at Columbia University, has two significant flaws.
Re ''Columbia Debates a Professor's 'Gesture' '' (news article, Oct. 19), about the school's response to Edward W. Said's throwing a rock toward an Israeli guardhouse from the Lebanese border:
It strikes me that the reasoning of Jonathan Cole, the provost and dean of faculties at Columbia University, has two significant flaws.

First, Mr. Cole stated that ''the stone was directed at no one.'' A stone directed at no one may certainly hit and seriously injure someone, and whatever his intent, the person throwing the stone is responsible.

The more troubling of the illogical, and to my mind insupportable, positions taken is that the action of stone-throwing could be seen as protected free speech. I don't believe that would be the case in this country. Speech stops at the point where assaultive action begins. Mr. Cole should rethink his position.
